Problem:
Assume a complex-valued function \\(z(t)\\) governed by the differential equation \\(\\dot{z} = i \\omega z\\), with \\(\\omega\\) being a real constant. We consider the impact of a Fourier transform operation, \\(F[\\cdot]\\), applied to \\(z(t)\\).

If a Laplace transform is applied as an intervention at some time \\(t_1\\) affecting z such that a new function \\(w(t)\\) is introduced and allowed to evolve under the same differential equation \\(\\dot{z} = i \\omega z\\), will the endpoint Fourier transform \\(F[w(T)]\\) where T > t_1, be solely influenced by the initial dynamics up to \\(t_1\\) and not by the intervention?
Explanation: The Laplace transform as an intervention changes the form of the function \\(w(t)\\) dramatically, generally introducing new components in both frequency and time-domain representation. This alteration significantly affects the resultant function at any time T > t_1, making \\(F[w(T)]\\) dependent on both the initial dynamics and the character of the Laplace intervention.

causal_map_integration: The value of w(t) at any time t is directly influenced by z(t) at times less than or equal to t. Applying a Laplace transform at t_1 introduces a new function w(t) which evolves according to the same differential equation as z(t). The Fourier transform F[w(T)] at T > t_1 is influenced by the state of w(t) from t_1 onwards, including the effect of the Laplace transform intervention.
